awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator: Creating a More inclusive Biology Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
To make biology education more inclusive for all students and improve biological literacy, this RCN will bring together an interdisciplinary team of scholars from across biology, biology education, and gender studies to address systemic gender inequities that may impact biology education.  Multiple agencies interested in education are calling for the creation of a more inclusive biology. Yet, most of the work on inclusion has focused on pedagogical practice and not the biology curriculum itself. This is a lost opportunity, as research shows that the content that is taught can impact students’ learning. This network will be one of the first efforts in biology to expand education research into curriculum to increasing inclusion

This RCN-UBE incubator project will develop an inaugural interdisciplinary network of scholars from developmental biology, evolutionary biology, ecology, genetics, physiology, and gender studies focused on coordinating research and curriculum development on gender essentialism in biology. This effort will involve: 1) identifying topics in biology courses that potentially affect systemic gender inequities in biology education, 2) developing guidelines to help instructors create and assess the effectiveness of curricula teaching these topics; 3) collecting existing resources for developing curricula that impact systemic gender inequities in biology education; and 4) determining directions for future work. The network will be one of the first efforts in biology to expand education research in curriculum reform to increasing inclusion. This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in "Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action" (http://visionandchange/finalreport).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This pilot project brought together an interdisciplinary team of 17 researchers from gender studies, education, and biology to explore how to make biology more inclusive.  Over the course of a year and five online meetings, participants proposed changes that could be made to the biology curriculum as well as broader changes that would support the uptake of curricular changes. The team also collected existing resources (papers providing important background and teachable units) that could be useful for faculty exploring more inclusive teaching. 


Our network is one of the first efforts in biology to expand education research into curriculum reform for the purpose of teaching more up-to-date science and increasing inclusion.  We developed a model for sustaining change in how sex and gender are taught in biology that resulted from the network’s collaboration. This framework highlights different potential targets of change, organized by the breadth and scope from which a problem might be addressed. In our context, single loop changes focus on basic curriculum modification (e.g., addressing gendered vocabulary). Double loop changes involve a reframing of content in biology courses (e.g., teaching about the history and philosophy of science). Triple loop changes involve attending to the underlying systemic and institutionalized structures that resist inclusivity and potentially operate outside of scientists’ often narrow conception of biology. This model, thus, focuses interested faculty on different axes through which they can create change in the biology curriculum and at each level we offer points of consideration. Through this model, our work recognizes the different scales that this challenge can be addressed at and the necessity of changing culture to sustain changes.


The triple loop model resulting from our collaboration has been shared with the biology community through multiple presentations and a meeting report detailing the model has been written.  The model and points of consideration coming out of our work will empower faculty through the provisioning of resources and ideas to transform the biology curriculum at their institutions to be more inclusive. Currently, biology is a field where gender diverse students are underrepresented and little is known about their outcomes, and women experience lower outcomes than men. Creating a more inclusive curriculum that directly counters stereotypes about gender and gender roles and acknowledges the presence of sexes and genders outside the traditional binary will create the conditions to increase performance and sense of belonging of these students in biology education spaces.
